newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Kuwait clears last of long-term foreign debt.
newsitem.headline: Kuwait clears last of long-term foreign debt.

text.p: Kuwait has cleared all its long-term foreign debts, repaying the final slice of a $5.5 billion sovereign loan used to rebuild the country after the 1991 Gulf War.
The Kuwait Investment Authority, the state's international borrowing and financial arm, said a last payment of $786 million was made on Thursday, the Kuwait News Agency reported.

"With the final payment Kuwait will have no outstanding long-term foreign debts," one banker earlier said of the jumbo loan which was taken out after a U.S.-led coalition freed Kuwait from a seven-month occupation by Iraq.
Some 80 banks from 19 countries contributed to the loan, arranged by J.P. Morgan and Co, which at the time was the largest ever made to a sovereign state.

Kuwait's Central Bank Governor Sheikh Salem Abdul-Aziz al-Sabah was quoted last year as saying his country, once one of the world's largest investors, would not borrow from international markets again.
The country's global investments have dropped to around $35 billion from over $100 billion mainly due to the huge Gulf War costs.

Kuwait's 4.21 billion dinar ($14 billion) budget for fiscal 1996/97 (July-June) projects a net deficit of 1.21 billion dinars. But it is based on oil revenue calculated at a weighted average price of $13 a barrel while current world prices for Kuwait's crudes are around $20 a barrel.
Kuwait produces about two million barrels of oil a day.
